Posts.Content: Jun 8, 2009 06:01AM ladydocsings wrote: Marsha N...i feel your pain.  i am finally now beyond that... there is a light at the end of the tunnel as they say.  I told everyone that the TE's felt like grapefruits duct-taped to my chest wall with a very tight underwire bra on.  i kept wanting to "pull that bra down" but it was inside.  It bothered me to drive...to back up and look behind.  i also couldn't sleep on either side so i essentially slept in the recliner chair for 5 months.  i did sleep for a while with 2 body pillows - one behind me to lean back on slightly and the other on the front between my knees, feet and to balance the smaller pillow i put on top of my "up" side, so my arm wasn't resting on the TE.  i had to sleep in the recliner again for a week post op (PS told me to), but i am back in bed and the recliner has been retired to its original room. And, i didn't have drains this time... i was THRILLED!  i do waken at night when i roll onto my side, but just because of a sense of pressure on the pectoralis muscle, not pain.  I am 4 weeks post exchange tomorrow.  I still have that spasm feeling or maybe muscle fasciculation with things like yawning, but much improved.  i was wondering if the location of the port for the instillation of saline makes a difference in part of the discomfort.  my muscles (pecs) were so sensitive just over the port area... i had the Mentor TE's that had the port on top that the PS had to localize with the magnet to fill.  Also with the fills - Ugh!  I had 120cc at operation and on day 8 post op he put in 150cc's ... that about killed me... put my out of commission for doing any Christmas shopping that whole weekend.  PS said that he wanted to fill me fast to put pressure on that Alloderm so the skin would incorporate it better.  Whatever.  I was finished with fills 5 weeks post op (he did 360cc total... i was a B pre-op and aiming for essentially the same size).  With each fill i was very uncomfortable...took ibuprofen and percocet. i also took neurontin (gabapentin) to try to decrease the sensitivity all around the edges... to sort of numb that hard edge.  it worked some but not 100%... it may have worked better had i used a higher dose (i am a hospice physician and do pain management), but i knew that i would want time to wean the med down because i was fairly certain i wasn't going to need it after the exchange. The point is, despite the discomfort, it is SOOOOOooo much better after the exchange is done.  Good luck to you.  There is an end to all of this.
Posts.Title: Is it just me? Expander driving me nuts! marcia-n makingway

Posts.Content: May 13, 2009 10:46AM ladydocsings wrote: HI Kim, I opted for skin-sparing BPM in December for 3 ADH plus ALH lesions, both breasts affected. My lesions were directly in the sub areolar/ under the nipple area so those had to go.  Previously i had nl mams.  i had TE's placed and just 2 days ago had my exchange done.  OMG, much softer.  My ports were on top and the pectoralis muscles were pretty irritated by them.  Of course i am pretty sore today... bruising and what not, but i seem more comfortable.  I did have fever and chills last night though, so i have to see my PS early tomorrow morning. Given the option of surveillance and or tamox, i would still have chosen BPM... it was right for me.  I personally saw no need for me to see a counsellor though. I am happy with my result so far.
Posts.Title: Atypia Hyperplasia-Now What? mkd1061 Petitegal127

Posts.Content: Jul 14, 2009 10:22PM ladydocsings wrote: Hi HellofromCT, Another from Ohio.  i don't get on the forum often (i think i'm having too much fun on facebook, LOL).  Three ADH lesions plus an are of ALH bilateral involvement with "lots of calcifications".  I had the biopsies last summer ('08), and had BPM with immed reconstruction (TE's, no flaps) in December and exchange 2 months ago.  My BS considered me very high risk; area of 50% lifetime risk.  The surgery was the right decision for me. I can't quite do what i used to...my PS has restricted me "for life" with the implants in...no moving furniture, heavy lifting, body building (yah right, LOL), so i've become a lightweight there...i do aerobics and core ball minus any workout using my pecs.  I do wake up at night with turning when i lay on my side, but tons better than with the TE's in. I am a little larger than i was pre-BPM, it doesn't bounce and no-one has a clue that I'm cold! Hehehe... I digress, but I'm glad i did what i did.  My insurance paid... my surgeons were in network, so after i met my deductible (met that with my ACL rupture and reconstruction there last fall), i had no out of pocket expense.  Of  course this year i am paying my deductible for the exchange.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic BLM for ADH? HelloFromCT Daudine

Posts.Content: Aug 25, 2009 10:28AM ladydocsings wrote: Hello CT & jll, I also had ADH...on three stereos 8/08.  Excisional bx confirmed same.  Didn't want 5 years of Tamox since my risk with 3 was ~50% and it would only reduce my risk of developing IBC to ~25% in my lifetime.  I had BPM with Allogerm and TE's and Exchange to silicone...last surgery was May and other than feeling pressure when rolling over in bed, I feel fine and very happy with my decision.  I had no bad side effect or complications, other than i couldn't sleep on either side for 5 months, so i committed myself to fitful sleep in the recliner pulled to the side of our bed.  But I would definitely do it again.  And I feel great that my risk is now what the general female population risk is ... ~5%.  Like a friend of mine said, going through similar surgery (though she had IDC with 1 LN+, unilat MX with Lat flap/TE and exchange), we now have a "new normal"...so true.
Posts.Title: Prophylactic BLM for ADH? HelloFromCT Daudine

Posts.Content: Jun 19, 2009 10:46PM ladydocsings wrote: Hi Floridian, I haven't gotten on this forum for a while...surgery (all good), recovery, sick mom, end of school year, yadda yadda. My BS said that because my disease was right underneath, they could not spare the nipple-areola complex.  if a lady has her abnormalities further away, then they can do the nipple-sparing procedure.  My excisional biopsies were done right at the edge of the areola on both sides.
Posts.Title: Atypia Hyperplasia-Now What? mkd1061 Petitegal127

Posts.Content: Feb 18, 2009 09:32PM ladydocsings wrote: Vickie, You know, the biannual "Breast mess" turns into "breast exam".  Since I had 3 ADH (with some ALH in the mix) and had the BPM with TE's, I since found out from my BS that i will still need clinical exam by her and my family doc, one each 6 months.  This will follow with the MRI's that will be needed once my silicone implants go in... the company rec's first at 3 years, then every 2 years, but my BS said that my PS does them yearly!  Even though my ins paid for the MRI i had last summer during my work-up, i'm betting they won't pay for yearly, but whatever the protocol is set up by the manufacturer.  At least the anxiety over the work-up in progress will be gone, Yeah!
